key_insight: Applying a Nesterov-style momentum scheme to ray-direction search (ARS-OPT) accelerates convergence to the minimal-ℓ2 adversarial ray, cutting the number of label queries needed for hard-label black‑box attacks.
problem_solved: Hard-label black‑box attacks require prohibitively many queries because only the top-1 label is available and finding the minimal perturbation direction (ray) is slow; this work reduces query complexity by improving the ray-search optimizer.
method: Introduce ARS-OPT: a momentum-based update on ray directions inspired by Nesterov’s Accelerated Gradient to speed directional search.
Combine the momentum updates with a query-efficient line/step search along each ray to find the minimal ℓ2 perturbation that crosses the decision boundary.
Provide theoretical analysis showing an improved convergence rate over vanilla ray-search and validate empirically with reduced queries and higher attack efficiency.
impact: Significantly fewer queries make hard-label attacks more practical for evaluating model robustness and for developing defenses; practitioners get a faster, theoretically grounded tool for black‑box robustness assessment.
visual_elements: Geometry diagram: benign image, decision boundary, candidate ray directions, and the minimal-ℓ2 adversarial perturbation along a ray.
Convergence/queries plot: ARS-OPT vs baseline showing iterations or queries on x-axis and distance-to-boundary / success rate on y-axis.
Algorithm flowchart: momentum update of ray direction + query-efficient line search steps (annotated with where queries are used).
Icon/metric panel: before vs after comparison showing % query reduction, attack success rate, and typical perturbation norms.
paper_title: Improving the Convergence Rate of Ray Search Optimization for Query-Efficient Hard-Label Attacks
paper_authors: Xinjie Xu, Shuyu Cheng, Dongwei Xu, Qi Xuan, Chen Ma
